result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Increased and diversified funding for MPAs

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Change in total annual central government budget allocated to MPA management.

target.comment: $780,517/yr (2014) /yr (increase of up to 21.3%)

actual.comment:
US$1.823.523/yr (2014)
The project estimated the total budget allocated by the government in 2014 including Cahuita NP, Santa Rosa NP, Playa Hermosa NWR, Coco´s Island Marine Conservation Area, Marine Program Coordinators in the 8 Conservations Areas that have MPAs

indicator.description: Change in the amount of financial resources received annually from private sources for the MPAs.

baseline.comment: $964,305/yr (2009) (indicate by source)

target.comment: $1,919,702/yr (increase of up to 99%)

actual.comment:
US$ 2,210,106.93/yr (2014)
(Includes financial expenses invested in 2014 for the MPAs by 7 NGOs and International Cooperation)

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Change in the financial gap to cover basic costs of management and investments of the MPAs

target.comment: $5,775,877 (14.8% reduction in the financial gap in existing MPAs)

actual.comment:
US$ 1.631.546.
The project estimated the financial gap existing in the three MPAs evaluated during the PPG (Cahuita NP, Santa Rosa NP, and Playa Hermosa NWR). The financial gap estimated were based on the actual budget and Management Plan Budget. Starting The project will attempt to make the estimation of all the MPAs that have a Management Plan already approved.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of business plans for the MPAs

baseline.comment: Zero (0)

target.comment: Three (3) approved by year 2

actual.comment:
One (1) approved by the MPA administration.
The Business Plan for Cahuita NP has been concluded and delivered, including three different mechanisms for increasing the funding for the PA. The other two business plans (Santa Rosa NP, and Playa Hermosa NWR), including the proposal of mechanisms for increasing the funding for the PA will be finalized by December 2015

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of proposals for implementing PES schemes in MPAs.

baseline.comment: Zero (0)

target.comment: Three (3)

actual.comment:
Three (3) : Available ecosystem services within the three MPAs were identified, characterized, classified and prioritized.
Then, SINAC selected two Ecosystem Services (Coastal Erosion Regulation and Touristic Services) to be valued in one of the three MPAs: Playa Hermosa NWR. As a result of the economic valuation to the Coastal Erosion Regulation service provided by the Playa Hermosa NWR, a proposal on Compensation Mechanism has been made in order to address funding for coastal erosion mitigation. The above proposal is currently being implemented through negotiations with stakeholders.
Based on the identification of Marine Ecosystem Services provided by the economic valuation mentioned before, the project team is working on a proposal that proactively identifies key environmental, cultural, economic and community attributes of surfing areas. This would allow the development of funding initiatives that can help increase financial sustainability for the area.
The project team has been working on proposals of Concessions of Non-essential Services (recreation and ecotourism) as schemes of Payment for Ecosystem Services in the three pilot MPAs (Cahuita NP, Santa Rosa NP, and Playa Hermosa NWR). The promotion of the development of a robust protected area tourism concession system through public-private partnerships can increase employment and livelihood opportunities in a sustainable and inclusive manner. The latter was presented as a mechanism for strengthening protected areas, increasing their financial sustainability

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Number MPAs expanded/created.

baseline.comment: Zero (0)

target.comment: 10 MPAs expanded/created (number of expanded and created MPAs will be defined during the first six months of project implementation)

actual.comment: In order to expand MPA coverage to improve ecological representation, the new Costa Rican government will support political decision once the process assures the implementation of governance models with local communities, based on the MPA Creation Guidelines specified in the ministerial directive (DM-475-2015). To comply with that directive, the project has emphasized the following processes: 1) For Santa Elena and Cabo Blanco sites, the conservation areas have come to have conservation agreements (signed) with coastal communities for the attention of coastal and marine resources. The next step would be to validate the processes and decree protected areas, 2) For Golfo Dulce, SINAC applied the "Guide to Marine Spatial Planning in Costa Rica" based on participatory dialogues and marine spatial planning, 3) For Chira - Tempisque, Dominical - Terraba, Caño Island, Corcovado, Barra del Colorado and Gandoca Manzanillo, Multisectoral platforms for dialogue and negotiation were established. Here, each group joints a common Proposal for decision making about marine and coastal resources.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Number of updated management plans for the MPAs in accordance with 10 priority sites

baseline.comment: Zero (0)

target.comment: Eleven (11)

actual.comment: In order to expand MPA coverage to improve ecological representation the new Costa Rican government will support political decision once the process assures the implementation of governance models with local communities, based on the MPA Creation Guidelines specified in the ministerial directive (DM-475-2015). The official declaration of new MPAs is required to start with their management plans, according to Costa Rican Biodiversity law. The governance models with local communities allow to define zoning, threats, stakeholders as a way to go forward with the process of management plans. So far One (1) Management Plan of the Sea Mounts Marine Protected Area.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: -Número de planes de gestión de riesgos de corrupción implementados por ASADA -Número de ASADAS implementado sistemas de monitoreo de desempeño financiero y operativo, y cuentan con línea de base.

baseline.comment: -Las ASADAS no cuentan con sistemas de mitigación de riesgos de corrupción, ni programas internos de formación en transparencia y rendición de cuentas -Las ASADAS no cuentan con sistemas de monitoreo de rendimiento financiero y operativo como parte de sus estrategias de rendición de cuentas.

target.comment: -Un 30% de las ASADAS del país cuentan con sistemas de gestión de riesgos de corrupción -El AyA cuenta con un sistema de información de la gestión de ASADAs que permita fiscalizar mejor la delegación de autoridad para suministro de agua -Un Programa Nacional de Capacitación Continua de Gestión de ASADAS, que incluya un componente de Transparencia y Rendición de Cuentas apoyado por el AyA y otras instituciones y el cuál será validado por medio de un taller nacional.

actual.comment: -Se han desarrollado 6 talleres de creación de capacidades para funcionarios de ASADAs en transparencia y rendición de cuentas. -37 ASADAS se han benficiado de apoyo tecnico para mejorar en temas de transparencia y rendición de cuentas. -37 ASADAS cuentan con planes, herramientas y políticas específicas para mejorar la transparencia y rendición de cuentas, y un adicional de 500 ASADAs recibirán entranamiento adicional através del programa de Educación Continua, lo que representa a más del 50% de las ASADAS del país. -Se están asegurando fondos para una nueva fase del Proyecto, que pretende la elaboración de un Kit de Herramientas para la Integridad del Manejo del Agua -CEDARENA ha identificado a los principales actores que proveen capacitación y los principales temas, los cuales se han correlacionado con las necesidades de entrenamiento de las ASADAs de acuerdo con la sistematización del AyA. - Se ha desarrollado el software y se ha incorporado a los rervidores e infraestructura de intranet del AyA. Deben iniciar con la utilización del mismo.

target.comment: -Un 30% de las ASADAS del país cuentan con sistemas de gestión de riesgos de corrupción -El AyA cuenta con un sistema de información de la gestión de ASADAs que permita fiscalizar mejor la delegación de autoridad para suministro de agua -Un Programa Nacional de Capacitación Continua de Gestión de ASADAS, que incluya un componente de Transparencia y Rendición de Cuentas apoyado por el AyA y otras instituciones y el cuál será validado por medio de un taller nacional. -Se cuenta con información en español para poder iniciar con trabajos en temas de saneamiento y manejo apropiado de lodos fecales.

actual.comment:
En Noviembre 2015 el AyA promulgó La Política Nacional de ASADAS, que incorpora un eje de transparencia y rendición de cuentas como parte de sus ejes de gestión.
-Un 25 % de las ASADAS del país cuentan con mejores conocimientos para desarrollar sistemas de gestión de riesgos de corrupción: Planes y polìticas diseñados y comprobados por el Proyecto (80 ASADAS) y capacitación en como formular esos planes a 500 ASADAS en eventos regionales y nacionales.
-Página web sistemas de programa de formación permanente de ASADAS vincula oferta con demanda de capacitación de ASADAS en el país, incorpora formación en transparencia y rendición de cuentas.
Datos de 280 ASADAS han sido ingresados al sistema de información de la gestión de ASADAs de AyA, que fortalece su gestión de datos.
El Programa Nacional de Capacitación Continua de Gestión de ASADAS, incluye un componente de Transparencia y Rendición de Cuentas apoyado por el AyA y otras instituciones y el cuál fue validado en un taller nacional Noviembre 2015.
Publicado en español libro de saneamiento y manejo apropiado de lodos fecales, fortalece acceso conocimientos sobre saneamiento útiles para ASADAS,

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: • Volumen de importación según las cuotas de importación de HCFC aprobadas para el año 2014. • No. de licencias de importación de HCFC y HFC concedidas durante el periodo. • Número de reuniones desarrolladas con la Dirección General de Aduanas (DGA), para detectar y contener el tráfico ilícito de CFC, con sus respectivas minutas. • Número de Oficiales de Aduanas y policía fiscal capacitados para el control de la importación de SAOs • Ideas de proyectos conjuntos para reducir el impacto sobre la capa de ozono y sobre el cambio climático, identificados. • Contar con equipos de refrigeración y aire acondicionado más eficientes en el mercado nacional. • Contar con un sistema de información ambiental en línea sobre HCFC y HFC. • Importadores, gases refrigerantes y de los equipos de refrigeración que los contengan, registrados. • Número de reuniones realizadas. • Página web de la OTO actualizada • Número de Capacitaciones realizadas • Material informativo diseñado e impreso • Número de actividades programadas con reporte de asistencia para conmemorar el día del Ozono.

baseline.comment: Trabajo previo en la Fase IX del proyecto de Fortalecimiento Institucional: Cumplimiento del compromiso adquirido sobre el esquema de reducción gradual de SAO, con la eliminación total del uso de CFC y de Bromuro de metilo como fumigante del suelo al 2013. Contar con un registro de importadores de SAO y equipos que utilizan gases refrigerantes para su operación. Dar continuidad y sostenibilidad al sistema de registro digital que ordena el otorgamiento de licencias para equipos y gases refrigerantes. Apoyo en la Implementación del “Plan para la eliminación de HCFC en Costa Rica” cuenta con un esquema de cuotas partiendo de una línea base y finalizando en 2030. Reportes periódicos y oportunos de importación y consumo de SAO al Fondo Multilateral y a la Secretaría del Ozono y otras sustancias de uso alternativo. Cumplir con los compromisos adquiridos por el país dentro del plan nacional para reducir el consumo de HCFC. Regulación de ingreso de sustancias y equipos que las contienen El país logra evitar el comercio ilícito de SAO desde sus fronteras. Contribución a la reducción del tráfico ilícito de SAO en la región Control de la importación de bromuro de metilo autorizada para cuarentena y pre-embarque que cumpla los requisitos técnicos para garantizar el uso racional y el menor impacto ambiental. Contar con una plataforma nacional autorizada por el Estado para disponer de los stocks de refrigerantes que agotan la capa de ozono entre otras de uso alternativo a estas. Reducción gradual del consumo de HCFC en el país. Modificación de la norma de eficiencia energética coordinada por la Dirección de Sectorial de Energía, en relación a los equipos de refrigeración y aire acondicionado. Promoción del uso de equipos con refrigerantes naturales como Propano (R-290), Isobutano (600a) o las mezclas de ambos. Ejecución de una cooperación conjunta con la Estrategia de Cambio Climático de Costa Rica para la reducción en el consumo de HCFC. Sistema de información en línea con i

target.comment: No sobrepasar la cuota nacional de importación de HCFC establecida para el año 2014. Contener al máximo el tráfico ilícito de SAO. Capacitar a 40 Oficiales de Adunas y policía Fiscal para el control de la importación de HCFC y HFC, evitando el tráfico ilícito. Reducción en el uso de equipos ineficientes que causan impacto negativo sobre el ambiente. Contar con Información veraz sobre Importadores e importaciones de HCFC y HFC, y equipos. 4 reuniones como mínimo durante el periodo de implementación del proyecto. Página web en operación y actualizada Población sensibilizada Material informativo distribuido Sectores vinculados y población en general consensuada y ocupada en realizar acciones para la protección de la capa de ozono

actual.comment: Se ha iniciado con el proceso de actualización (información y diseño) de la página web de la Oficina Técnica del Ozono. Se espera que esté operativa y con información actualizada en los primeros meses de 2015. Se llevan a cabo talleres de capacitación para oficiales de Aduanas y Policía Fiscal, sobrepasando la meta de oficiales capacitados. Se llevan a cabo inspecciones de importacion de SAOs. Se celebra el día del Ozono, con acciones de sensibilización y educación.

target.comment: No sobrepasar la cuota nacional de importación de HCFC establecida para el año 2014. Capacitar a 100 Oficiales de Adunas y policía Fiscal para el control de la importación de HCFC y HFC, evitando el tráfico ilícito. Reducción en el uso de equipos ineficientes que causan impacto negativo sobre el ambiente. Contar con Información veraz sobre importadores de SAOS y los equipos que las contengan. Contar con Información veraz sobre importaciones de HCFC y HFC, y equipos. 4 reuniones como mínimo durante el periodo de implementación del proyecto. Página web en operación y actualizada Población sensibilizada Material informativo distribuido

actual.comment: -Implementación de un sistema de licencias para la importación o exportación de sustancias que agotan la capa de ozono y producen calentamiento global como los Hicroclorofluocarbonos (HCFC) y los Hidrofluorocarbonos (HFC), así como para aquellos equipos de refrigeración o climatización que las contengan. Esto se realiza mediante la aplicación de reglamentos, que en su momento fueron desarrollados en el marco de este proyecto. En promedio de tramitan alrededor de 500 solicitudes de importación o exportación al mes. -Coordinación con la Dirección General de Aduanas, y la Promotora de Comercio Exterior para la capacitación de los oficiales de la policía de control fiscal, con el fin de que nos apoyen a reducir el tráfico ilícito de estas sustancias. A la fecha se han decomisado cerca de 400 cilindros (5,5 tonelas) de HCFC que ingresaron de manera ilícita al país y se gestiona su eliminación. -Implementación de un sistema de licencias para la importación o exportación de sustancias que agotan la capa de ozono y producen calentamiento global como los Hicroclorofluocarbonos (HCFC) y los Hidrofluorocarbonos (HFC), así como para aquellos equipos de refrigeración o climatización que las contengan. Esto se realiza mediante la aplicación de reglamentos, que en su momento fueron desarrollados en el marco de este proyecto. En promedio de tramitan alrededor de 500 solicitudes de importación o exportación al mes. -Generación de reportes país de importación y exportación de sustancias agotadoras de la capa de ozono al amparo del artículo 7 del Protocolo de Montreal. -Establecimiento de sinergias con el sector industrial (importadores) para reducir gradualmente el consumo de sustancias agotadoras de ozono, e impulsar la transferencia de tecnología. -Ampliación de la red de monitoreo del índice de radiación ultravioleta en las diferentes regiones. Esto se realiza en coordinación con el Instituto Meteorológico Nacional. El índice se publica para 7 regiones de manera diaria. -Coordi

result.title: Objective
result.description: Minimize risks of exposure from PCBs to people and the environment in Costa Rica.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Quantity of PCBs (liquids and solids) destroyed in the project period (2013-2017).
Quantity of PCB material safeguarded.

baseline.comment:
1000 MT PCBs destroyed pre- project through exports and in-country treatment.
National inventory but outdated.

target.comment:
1350 MT of PCBs (liquids and solids) disposed of in an environmentally sound manner.
All known PCBs safely stockpiled.

actual.comment:
112 TM of oil and equipment were decontaminated. The oil were contained in 285 transformers.
The owner of this oil was CNFL (distribution Company in Metropolitan Area), decontamination was done locally by dechlorination, the process was carried out from January through the first days of June 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of environmental, health and customs authorities' personnel trained to monitor compliance of Stockholm Convention requirements and national norms.

baseline.comment: Environmental, health and customs authorities' personnel do not have the knowledge and training to execute control and monitoring of the PCB stockpiles in the country.

target.comment: 30 officials of the environmental, health and commerce authorities trained to control the commerce, storage, transport, treatment and final disposal of PCBs, 1 Norm developed and validated 4 guidelines / manuals developed by end of the project

actual.comment:
1 training on the use of L2000 DX analytical equipment, which is included in the technical guidance, was conducted.
Norm on identification and elimination of PCB was developed and validated, and its waiting ministerial approval and signature
The technical guidance on enviramental sound management of PCB is being reviewed to be printed later in the year.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of safe PCB management and disposal options

baseline.comment: The country has no centralized facility for treatment PCB contaminated transformers

target.comment: At least one treatment/disposal alternative (interim storage/transfer station) in operation at the end of the project.

actual.comment:
One alternative treatment (dechlorination) was identified locally and is in operation.
The project has visited and has knowledge of the process and the technology involved.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number companies trained and implementing the new regulatory guidelines

baseline.comment: No guidelines for PCB management in place

target.comment: 8 companies trained and implementing the new regulatory guidelines.

actual.comment:
49 technicians in total from 8 companies have been trained in the inventory requirements and the PCB identification process. Training has been done in sample taking and semi-quantitative analysis for PCB.
However since the technical guide is not yet published, full training on it has not been carried out.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of inspectors / enforcement officers trained to enforce national laws / norms on PCB management

baseline.comment: Limited knowledge about PCB management among environmental inspectors.

target.comment: 20 maintenance and other personnel at PCB holders trained in safe PCB handling. 4 inspectors/enforcement officers trained to enforce national laws/norms on PCB management.

actual.comment: 49 technical personnel from 8 companies have received training in information collection for the inventory in a safe manner..

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Strengthened Institutional Capacity in Costa Rica for the environmentally sound management of PCBs.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of PCB management regulations developed and validated by regulating institution.

baseline.comment: PCB management is not established by regulations and norms that guarantee their environmentally sound management.

target.comment: PCB management regulations and environmentally sound management norms developed and validated.

actual.comment: One regulation,: " Regulation for the identification and environmentally safe elimination of PCB". Drafted with support of the project is presently undergoing in public consultation process

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of inspectors trained to conduct site visits for the verification of compliance of the regulations for PCB management.

baseline.comment: The regulating institution does not have trained inspectors that can evaluate the environmentally sound management of PCBs.

target.comment: At least 4 inspectors trained in PCB management evaluation and enforcement.

actual.comment: 2 officials from Dirección de Gestión de Calidad Ambiental , DIGECA, are in process of being trained in general PCB management concepts, the use of L2000 analytical equipment, and sample taking.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of inspections carried out during project implementation (2013-17)

baseline.comment: Currently contaminated sites have not been identified. The national inventory was done in 2005 and was based on out of service equipment and primarily with Clor-N- Oil testing.

target.comment: At least1 inspection made by inspectors to each electrical sector company per semester.

actual.comment: This has not been started because the regulation has to be first approved to be able to start inspections.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of potential contaminated sites Number of national inventories updated on line with information from electrical companies on contaminated equipment and oils identified and inventories eliminated.

baseline.comment: Currently one annual report is submitted to the SC Secretariat.

target.comment: A preliminary inventory of potentially PCB contaminated sites. PCB data base operating with on line reporting from electrical sector companies with inventory update information.

actual.comment:
A consultant company is in the process of being hired to conduct an evaluation of a determined number of potentially PCB contaminated sites.
The PCB information system is operating and all companies have on line access. All companies are providing their information.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of reports submitted to the Stockholm Convention Secretariat

target.comment: 1 annual report on PCBs submitted to the Stockholm Convention Secretariat.

actual.comment: The Stockholm Convention Report # 3 for all COPs of 2014 was sent to the BRS secretariat in December 2014.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: National PCB Management and Elimination Plan

target.comment: National PCB Management and Elimination Plan approved and in implementation process

actual.comment: This process has not started as it is awaiting information from the inventory.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Environmentally sound management and interim storage of PCBs,

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of Electrical sector companies with PCB management plans, developed and presented to national authority for approval.

baseline.comment: There is a lack of a national environmental management plan that includes an elimination plan so that electrical companies can use as guidelines for their activities, regarding their PCB issues.

target.comment: PCB environmentally sound management practices implemented in at least 7 electrical sector companies.

actual.comment: Training in Best Practices is planned for 30 technicians, once the technical guidance is published. The Evaluation of Storage sites will be conducted in 23 locations.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Technical standards for the environmentally sound management of PCBs approved.

baseline.comment: No guidelines and technical standards are currently being used

target.comment: 7 PCB owners with management plans presented to regulating institution and compliance verified.

actual.comment: This has not been started because the proposed regulation has to be approved to verify these plans.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of Occupational health and safety guidelines issued and implemented by electrical sector companies.

baseline.comment: Occupational health and safety issues are important when evaluating potential risk for workers who have already been exposed to PCBs in the past and to prevent future incidents

target.comment: 1 set of Guidelines and technical standards for management of PCB equipment established and implemented (transportation, storage, management and disposal).

actual.comment: The Technical Guidelines for PCB Environmental Management have been developed by the technical leader of the project and approved by the Follow-up Committee within DIGECA (includes transport, storage, management and final disposal topics).

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of trainers trained on Best practices for PCB Management

baseline.comment: No trainers trained.

target.comment: 1 set of national occupational health and safety standards for PCB management formulated for national application, approved by regulating authority and in operation in electrical sector companies. A minimum of 10 trainers trained on Best Practices for PCB management.

actual.comment: The health and occupation safety standards are included in the Technical Guidelines. The training of trainers has not started yet.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of Designs for Interim storage/transfer station.

baseline.comment: No design for interim storage/transfer station exists currently.

target.comment: 1 Design for interim storage/transfer station developed according to international best practices.

actual.comment: The evaluation of storage sites to determine the need to design a transfer station is currently on-going.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Number of Environmental Impact Assessments for Interim storage/transfer station.

baseline.comment: No EIAs prepared.

target.comment: 1 Environmental impact assessment developed and approved.

actual.comment: This will depend on the Transfer Station design.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Number of Technical standards developed for interim storage/transfer station.

baseline.comment: No Technical standards for interim storage/transfer station have been developed.

target.comment: Technical standards developed and implemented according to national conditions for Interim storage/transfer station, including design, operation, interim storage, and management of hazardous substances

actual.comment: Technical standards for interim storage/transfer stations have been developed as part of the Technical Guidelines.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Interim storage/transfer station built and ready for operation.

baseline.comment: No interim storage/transfer station in operation.

target.comment: 1 Interim storage/transfer station in operation according to developed standards and national law.

actual.comment: The start of this is pending the results of the storage site evaluation consultancy.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Environmentally sound destruction of PCBs and management of contaminated equipment.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: National Coordination mechanism established among PCB holders and government companies in operation.

baseline.comment: The only option for the decontamination, treatment and disposal of PCB contaminated equipment and oils is through exportation to installations at very high cost.

target.comment: National Coordination mechanism operating.

actual.comment:
Steering Committee is active, it holds annual meetings and the Technical Advisory Committee holds monthly meetings. The National Coordination mechanism is made up of these two entities.
Project team complete including National Coordinator, Technical Leader and three officials from DIGECA (Dirección de Gestión de Calidad Ambiental) .

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Environmentally sound destruction of existing PCB inventory

baseline.comment: There is no technically and economically viable alternative to exporting which needs to be developed, in order for the PCB owners to complete the elimination process and fulfill the Stockholm Convention goals

target.comment: A feasibility study completed to determine the best available technological alternative and the interim storage/transfer station options.

actual.comment:
Pending, subject to results of inventory completion and the evaluation of storage sites consultancy.
The previously decontaminated 55 TN were from an individual initiative carried out by an important electric company (Compañìa Nacional de Fuerza y Luz).
The companies were provided PCB analysis equipment (handhelds and L2000DX) to complete the inventory in an efficient and timely manner.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Feasibility study for interim storage/transfer station administration completed.

target.comment: Environmentally sound alternative for decontamination, treatment and disposal of PCB contaminated equipment and oils made available for electrical sector companies and other PCB owners.

actual.comment: One local company with alternative treatment identified and in operation, which has been assessed by the project team.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of agreements between PCBs holders to develop interim storage/transfer station.

baseline.comment: No formal agreement exists among the 7 PCB holders in the country.

target.comment: Public Private Partnership developed for the interim storage/transfer station administration. 1 agreement reached between interested parties regarding interim storage/transfer station operation.

actual.comment: Pending the results form the inventory and the evaluation of storage site consultancy.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of feasibility studies to determine if low concentration PCB oils s can be destroyed locally.

baseline.comment: Low concentration PCB oils cannot be destroyed locally and no study has been conducted to evaluate the feasibility

target.comment: 1 study to determine if PCB contaminated oils with less than 5.000 ppm are destroyed locally (where ODS will be destroyed).

actual.comment: Pending the results of the pilot project for the destruction of ODS that is currently on-going in Costa Rica. The results are expected to be presented by the end of the year.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of Awareness raising and communications strategies developed.

baseline.comment: Currently no awareness raising and communication strategy has been developed regarding PCBs and the risk it poses to the people and the environment.

target.comment: 1 Awareness raising strategy developed and implemented with the main stakeholders (electrical sector companies, regulating institutions and general public).

actual.comment:
Communication strategy developed and in the process of being validated by the electrical sector companies.
A communication protocol is being developed, to be implemented in case of a communicative emergency, including the definition of the possible spokesmen and messages.
A total of 25 persons were trained on general PCB management concepts and the communication strategy was presented and validated.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of workshops with populations living close to Interim storage/transfer station

baseline.comment: Physical location of interim storage/transfer station has not yet been determined, and therefore no communication exists with potentially affected population.

target.comment: 4 Community workshops carried out for population living close to the interim storage/transfer station to inform about the benefits of interim storage/transfer station in terms of environmental protection and technical safeguards put in place for the operation. Regular workshops on a yearly basis as follow up this activity.

actual.comment: Pending. Subject to the determination of the need or not to establish a transfer station.

result.title: Outcome 5
result.description: Monitoring, adaptive feedback, outreach and evaluation.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of high quality monitoring and evaluation documents prepared during project implementation

baseline.comment: No documents in baseline situation.

target.comment:
4 Quarterly Operational Reports submitted to UNDP each year
1 annual APR/PIR submitted to UNDP each year.
1 Mid-term evaluation.
1 Final evaluation
MTE and FE must include a lessons learned section and a strategy for dissemination of project results.

actual.comment:
The first APR/PIR was submitted in July 2015.
In place of quarterly reports, bimonthly monitoring meetings are carried out.
In May 2015 a financial - accounting audit was done

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: P1: Suma de personal que terminó el programa de capacitación técnica, personal que terminó el programa de alfabetización y personal que terminó la capacitación en el tema de la empleabilidad en personas con discapacidad en el modelo social. P2: Implementación de campaña de divulgación en el 2013 y 2014 P3: Número de personas capacitadas en negocios inclusivos fuera y dentro del Área Metropolitana, número de publicaciones escritas sobre el tema de empleadores inclusivos, número de spots radiofónicos sobre el tema de empleadores inclusivos P4: Número de representantes de empleadores capacitados y caja de herramientas en línea P5: Empresas participantes en talleres de la REI P6: Número de empresas reconocidas P7: Número de empresas que manifiestan su interés de emplear a grupos de PcD P8: Planes de trabajo CTIEPcD y de todas las comisiones establecidos y en ejecución a tiempo de acciones planificadas y metas alcanzadas. Producto 8: Consolidación de gobernanza del Plan y estrategia de sostenibilidad Protocolos de prácticas amigables a los servicios de PcD oficializados y puestos en práctica 2013 Coordinación del Plan pasa a funcionario de MTSS 2014 y estrategia de sostenibilidad ha sido desarrollada

target.comment: P1: 80 miembros del personal de instituciones que atienden a personas con discapacidad (PcD) terminan las capacitaciones en alfabetización de PcD, actualización de especialidades técnicas, y/o en el tema de la empleabilidad en personas con discapacidad en modelo social P2: 150 PcD adicionales en cursos de formación del INA, 75 PcD adicionales en cursos del MEP, 500 PcD con subsidios del IMAS o CPJ P3: 75 representantes de empleadores capacitados 2 publicaciones escritas 2 spots radiofónicos P4: Difusión de caja de herramientas, al menos directamente a 75 representantes de empleadores capacitados P5: 30 empresas participan de talleres de la REI fuera de la GAM P6: Premiación 10 empresas P7: 15-25 empresas interesadas P8: Personal de organizaciones participantes asumen rol de liderazgo y funciones concretas y desarrollan estrategia para sostenibilidad

actual.comment: Al 12 de diciembre de 2014, de las 2.300 personas con discapacidad cuyo perfil de empleabilidad mejoraría por medio de las acciones de capacitación técnica y laboral, se logró atender a 1.179 personas, lo cual representa un 51% de la meta establecida por el Proyecto. De estas 1.179 personas, 681 fueron capacitadas por docentes del MEP (acción 1.1.); 351 se graduaron de programas de capacitación del INA o del Programa Empléate del MTSS; y 147 matriculados en opciones de formación y desarrollo de competencias en el marco del Protocolo de Coordinación Interinstitucional, con apoyo del INA o del MTSS . Es importante analizar la contribución de estos resultados a la eliminación de los cuellos de botella prioritarios identificados para este eje en el PNILPcD, los cuales consistían en: la limitada oferta educativa para propiciar la empleabilidad de las personas con discapacidad; la insuficiente formación de los docentes para propiciar la adecuada preparación de los estudiantes con discapacidad; la escasa divulgación de los servicios de apoyo educativo y formativo; y la poca coordinación entre programas de formación, necesidades de mercado y facilitación laboral . El proceso de mejoramiento del perfil de empleabilidad es una labor muy compleja, si se entiende en términos del desarrollo de “las competencias y cualificaciones transferibles que refuerzan la capacidad de las personas para aprovechar las oportunidades de educación y de formación que se les presenten con miras a encontrar y conservar un trabajo decente, progresar en la empresa o al cambiar de empleo y adaptarse a la evolución de la tecnología y de las condiciones del mercado de trabajo”. Este concepto acuñado por la OIT implica que la persona debe desarrollar un conjunto de capacidades y habilidades que le permitan conseguir un empleo, mantenerlo o encontrar uno nuevo, entre las cuales se incluye el aprendizaje continuo y la adaptación a las exigencias del entorno laboral. En este sentido, la formación para l

target.comment: 1. Potenciar el perfil de empleabilidad de las personas con discapacidad mediante la gestión de procesos de formación, dirigidos a desarrollar competencias básicas requeridas para su participación en el mercado laboral. 2. Expandir la demanda laboral de personas con discapacidad a través de la concientización, asesoría e involucramiento de más empleadores inclusivos. 3. Fortalecer los servicios de intermediación laboral para personas con discapacidad mediante la creación de herramientas y el trabajo en red. 4. Fomentar el desarrollo de emprendimientos de personas con discapacidad a través de la gestión de servicios de asesoría técnica, capacitación y créditos, que sean accesibles a esta población, promoviendo sus capacidades emprendedoras 5. Promover las sinergias institucionales y la articulación de acciones dirigidas hacia la inserción laboral de Personas con Discapacidad

actual.comment:
Principales resultados alcanzados por componente del proyecto
Impacto general: 549 personas con discapacidad se encuentren generando su propio ingreso, 500 contratadas por empleadores y 49 desarrollando emprendimientos grupales e individuales, logrando alcanzar la meta propuesta por el proyecto de que al menos 200 personas con discapacidad al año se encontraran generando su propio ingreso.
Componente 1: Mayores oportunidades de formación para las personas con discapacidad • 1.653 jóvenes con discapacidad han mejorado su perfil de empleabilidad distribuidos de la siguiente manera: 681 estudiantes con discapacidad capacitados por docentes del MEP que participaron en talleres de alfabetización, modelo social y empleabilidad; 505 personas con discapacidad graduadas de programas de capacitación técnica del INA; 382 entrenadas en cursos de formación técnica a través de la estrategia Empléate Inclusivo del MTSS; 85 jóvenes con discapacidad capacitados en cursos de habilidades blandas con recursos del CPJ. • Elaboración y puesta en marcha del Protocolo de coordinación interinstitucional MTSS-INA-MEP para atender las necesidades de formación básica e inserción laboral de las personas con discapacidad. Componente 2: Expansión de la demanda laboral: empleadores inclusivos • 60 empresas se han afiliado a la Red de Empresas Inclusivas de Costa Rica (REI) y han empezado a implementar prácticas más inclusivas de personas con discapacidad producto de su participación en el programa de capacitación de esta red. Como resultado de su participación entre el año 2012 al 2015, estas empresas han contratado a un total de 443 personas con discapacidad en puestos de trabajo administrativos, operativos y técnicos. (371 fueron contratadas entre el 2013 y 2014) • Lanzamiento del “Reconocimiento Costa Rica Incluye” para incentivar prácticas inclusivas de personas con discapacidad en los empleadores. Entre el 2014 y 2015 se han realizado dos ediciones de este reconocimiento y recientemente

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: -Ejecución Presupuestaria del Proyecto -Cumplimiento del AWP -Adecuado seguimiento de actividades -Un documento que cumpla con los contenidos establecidos en este Addendun, el cual debe ser avalado por Fonafifo.

baseline.comment: -Poca incursión en el establecimiento de un Sistema Nacional en materia ambiental, ni en el desarrollo de indicadores para la medición del impacto ambiental de proyectos y programas. -El país cuenta con muchos mecanismos de coordinación y de información de estadísticas y de indicadores, pero con la ausencia de la inclusión del tema ambiental en muchos de ellos, por tal razón, se cuenta con una base de indicadores los cuales deben ser valorados en su eficacia y eficiencia para medir salvaguardas y co beneficios. Sin embargo, para toda la legislación y procedimientos vigentes de Salvaguardas con que cuenta el país aún no existe un Sistema Nacional de Información para atender disposiciones de la Convención de Cambio Climático en la materia. -Costa Rica no cuenta con Sistema que informe sobre el abordaje y cumplimiento de las salvaguardas de REDD de la CMNUCC, que cumpla con sus acuerdos y orientaciones. -Costa Rica no cuenta con un Sistema de Información sobre salvaguardas, y sobre una metodología ajustada a nivel nacional para diseñarlo.

target.comment: -Contar con el recurso humano especializado para el desarrollo de los productos del proyecto con un mecanismo de comunicación colectiva y con materiales audiovisuales que recopilan las acciones realizadas con las PIR. -Contar con un análisis del contexto en el cual se diseña e implementará el Sistema de Información, con una definición de los objetivos del Sistema, y con el registro de la información y los PRL (políticas, leyes, reglamentos, directrices, pronunciamientos, etc) que tiene Costa Rica para el abordaje y cumplimiento de las salvaguardas de REDD de la CMNUCC. -Contar con un diseño del Sistema de Información sobre el abordaje y cumplimiento de Costa Rica de las salvaguardas de REDD de la CMNUCC, validada con Partes e instituciones relevantes para las acciones del R-PP, y con usuarios del Sistema. -Contar con una sistematización del proceso de desarrollo del proyecto para la generación por primera vez, de un sistema de información sobre salvaguardas -Disponer de una sistematización del desarrollo de comunicaciones para el proyecto, y de lecciones aprendidas, que sean un referente para el desarrollo de iniciativas similares en otros país con contextos similares

actual.comment: El proceso desarrollado con el proyecto permite confirmar la intención original, de contar con información e indicadores que permitan a la institución responsable de REDD, verificar mediante el SIS REDD el impacto de las medidas (políticas, programas, proyectos, etc) en relación con el nivel de emisiones por degradación y deforestación forestal, y también el cumplimiento de las salvaguardas adoptadas por la COP 16. De conformidad con el PRODOC y sus Adendas, se continúa aspirando que los indicadores constituyan un estándar contra el cual evaluar, estimar o demostrar el progreso con respecto a objetivos y metas de las medidas REDD de Costa Rica. Pese a que la aspiración precitada, en ausencia de las medidas REDD, de la Estrategia, del Nivel de Referencia y del MRV no pudo ser concretada, el proyecto ha logrado incluir el SIS REDD en el marco conceptual del CENIGA, lo que obliga a la institución responsable a utilizar los protocolos y metodologías establecidas para el Sistema de Información ambiental. De esta forma, la inclusión en el SINIA busca atender debilidades identificadas por el CENIGA sobre los sistemas de información de Costa Rica. Por otra parte, la inclusión en el SINIA pretende que la institución responsable de REDD al atender las directrices del CENIGA oficializadas por el MINAE, logre contar con indicadores explícitos, disponibles, claros para los usuarios, y específicos. Un aspecto clave es la recolección de la información permita construir el mismo indicador, de la misma manera, de tal forma que las comparaciones sean válidas. De igual forma, el indicador deberá ser sensible a los cambios, para poder medir qué tanto el indicador se desvía (a favor o en contra) de la efectividad de una política REDD. En este sentido, la propuesta de indicadores (Cuadro 8 y 9) puede resultar no relevante ni oportuna para la aplicación de las políticas, por cuanto el proyecto requería de conocimiento sobre la situación prevaleciente en los diferentes sectores para poder

result.title: Objective
result.description: To mainstream the international commitments derived from the Rio Conventions into targeted national environmental legislation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: A targeted set of improved capacities to meet and sustain Rio Convention objectives is improved. Commitments under the Rio Conventions will have been strengthened and institutionalized. Existing national development strategies, plans and programmes will better support a more harmonized approach to implementing existing environmental legislation

baseline.comment: Capacities to implement the Rio Conventions are not sustainable, requiring donor-funded projects. Commitments to implement the Rio Conventions are measured through Rio Convention-specific instruments. National environmental policy instruments contain provisions that counteract each other and are weakly implemented

target.comment:
Rio Convention obligations are being better implemented through existing environmental legislation, 15% increase in survey value response
A year-end analysis of environmental legislation shows an improvement in institutional responses to monitoring and enforcing environmental legislation for the Rio Conventions.
There is a minimum of 20% increase in the understanding of the Rio Convention mainstreaming among government staff
There is a minimum of 15% increase in the appreciation of the Rio Conventions among the general public

actual.comment: Overall Project objective is on track. In spite of delays in inception, MEA focal meetings and strategic support for Costa Rica's National Biodiversity Strategy and Policy and National Contribution under the UNFCCC have allowed for a an improvement in the implementation of the Rio Conventions. Institutional arrangements for cross-cutting approaches are being developed through the strengthening of the Presidential Council for the Environment, with line Ministries from Agriculture, Transport, Health, Tourism, among others.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Integrated inter-ministerial decision-making process for the global environment strengthened

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1.1 Strengthened MEA technical Committees
Awareness and understanding of Rio Convention (MEA) technical committee members
?Frequency of MEA technical committee meetings
Policy recommendations submitted by MEA technical committee to Inter-Ministerial Council
Technical recommendations submitted to line ministries and agencies

baseline.comment:
1.1 Strengthened MEA technical Committees
Advisory commissions exist as equivalents of MEA technical committee, but they meet on an ad hoc basis and there is communication and coordination among them
There is some representation of non-state actors in the advisory commission for biodiversity, but not for the climate change or land degradation
The work of the advisory commissions does not effectively contribute to government actions doe to unclear attribution of responsibilities

target.comment:
1.1 Strengthened MEA technical Committees
Baseline survey of decision-makers’ and planners’ awareness carried out with N100 participants, completed by month 4 of the project.
Year-end survey of decision-makers’ and planners’ awareness carried out with N250 participants, completed by month 32 of the project.
Three (3) MEA technical committees (CBD, CCD, and FCC) are created by month 4 with a membership of expert stakeholder representation of at least 10 different stakeholders (government, NGOs, academia, private sector, and civil society). The technical committees will meet at least three (3) times per year.
MEA technical committees submit policy recommendations to the Inter-Ministerial Council twice (2) a year, the first by month 9.

actual.comment: MEA technical committee has met three times during reporting period to approve annual workplan and set priorities for Year 1 of Project implementation. National project coordinator presented partial workplan on consultations for the UNFCCC National Contribution to the Presidential Council for the Environment. Two interministerial committee meetings were held on climate change, with inputs from Project staff. A National Survey on Climate Change conducted by UNDP Costa Rica under the LEDS Project has been useful as a baseline survey on the public perception on the need for policies for a low carbon and resilient development strategy in the country. The survey included a sample size of 1203 persons, in a country-wide telephone poll, with a confidence level of 95% and an estimated margin of error of 2.8%. Meetings with non-state actors, including private sector and NGOs, have enable to identify weakness in the representation of civil society organizations in the current MEA governance structure, which will require strengthening during year 2.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
1.2 Strengthened information sharing agreements with academia and civil society
Baseline analysis of information needs for the global environment
Feasibility study for the strengthening of an electronic information-sharing mechanism
An information-sharing agreement signed by MINAE and key non-state actors (same as in output 2.2)

baseline.comment:
1.2 Strengthened information sharing agreements with academia and civil society
Much data and information relevant to the Rio Conventions exists, but for the most part is not in a form that readily lends itself to sharing electronically.
Data and information is largely accessible on an ad hoc basis
There are multiple electronic sources of information, but do not contain all useful data and information

target.comment:
1.2 Strengthened information sharing agreements with academia and civil society
In-depth baseline analysis substantively peer reviewed by at least 8 national experts, and completed by month 5 of the project
Feasibility study for the strengthening of an existing electronic platform and internet interface prepared and completed by month 7.
Independent assessment of the performance of the electronic information system as implemented under 3.5.1 by month 30.
Agreement signed by MINAE and key non-state actors on the sharing of information by month 18

actual.comment: Support provided to strengthen data gathering and information sharing arrangements under the MINAE National Environmental Information System. Existing platform for information sharing will be strengthened and opened to a larger number of stakeholders. The only focal point with a operational platform for exchange of information is the UNCCD. The Advisory Commission on Land Degradation (CADETI) includes representatives from Academia, NGOs, Ministry of Agriculture and Ministry of the Environment. CADETI reviews land degradation policies, provide technical inputs into policy goals and review the effectiveness of existing practices to reduce land degradation. More support to CADETI is planned for Year 2 of the project. By end of Project, we hope to support the development of a policy for open data for environmental information in Costa Rica.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
1.3 Re-invigorated Inter-Ministerial Council meetings
Cooperative agreements on legislative oversight with Inter-Ministerial Council members and other line ministries
Meetings of the Inter-Ministerial Council
Inter-Ministerial Council supports MEA technical committee recommendations

baseline.comment:
1.3 Re-invigorated Inter-Ministerial Council meetings
There is no formal agreement among ministries to reconcile overlapping oversight of environmental and related legislation
The Inter-Ministerial Council only meets to discuss climate change issues.

target.comment:
1.3 Re-invigorated Inter-Ministerial Council meetings
Key ministries sign relevant agreements by month 12.
Inter-Ministerial Council meets twice (2) per year to discuss and approve MEA technical committee recommendations, and before month 9
At least 80% of the MEA technical committee recommendations are supported by appropriate inter-ministerial decisions by month 34

actual.comment: Two meetings of the interministerial committee for climate change have included in their agenda presentations from National Project Coordinator. A presentation before the Presidential Council on the environment provided the political support for a cross-cutting multi-stakeholder, multi-sectoral consultation on Costa Rica's National Contribution to the UNFCCC. Joint working groups between Ministries of Environment and Agriculture strengthened, on livestock and climate change.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Cross-cutting Rio Convention provisions are integrated into environmental legislation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
2.1 In-depth analysis of environmental legislation and its governance
Roster of expert peer reviewers on the global environment created
Rio Convention analytical framework
Targeted analytical reports on environmental governance per the Rio Conventions
Stakeholder consultations on Rio Convention governance at the national level
Regional and non-state representation in stakeholder constituent dialogues
Consensus agreements from MEA technical committee on recommendations for improved environmental governance

baseline.comment:
2.1 In-depth analysis of environmental legislation and its governance
There are many experts working on most, if not all, aspects of the Rio Conventions
There are many analyses pertaining to the Rio Conventions, but most all are focused on reporting requirements
There are numerous stakeholder consultations, but most all are either targeted to focal area or sustainable development objectives
Regional and non-state stakeholders participate in many government-sponsored consultative dialogues, but these are nearly all very targeted to focal area or sustainable development interventions
? Technical recommendations by the advisory commissions do not take into account similar technical recommendations by other advisory commissions

target.comment:
2.1 In-depth analysis of environmental legislation and its governance
A roster of peer reviewers with minimum 50 experts is created by month 3
Analytical framework prepared and completed by month 6
At least five (5) independent peer reviewers rate the framework of high quality
Four (4) in-depth analyses targeting Costa Rica’s environmental governance from a Rio Convention perspective completed by month 10
Synthesis analysis is endorsed by all members of the MEA technical working groups and the MEA technical committee by month 12
MEA technical committee drafts policy recommendations for the Inter-Ministerial Council by month 14
All reports are discussed and validated at open-ended stakeholder dialogues within two months of their completion
Each stakeholder constituent dialogue is attended by at least 30 representatives that cover the range of stakeholder views and perspectives.
Each stakeholder constituent dialogue endorses the analyses and offers broad support for endorsement by the MEA technical committee and subsequent approval by the Inter-Ministerial Council.
At least two (2) stakeholder representatives from each of the seven (7) provinces have participated in at least one of the stakeholder constituent dialogues by month 33.

actual.comment: Roster of peer reviewers created. Analytical framework for the analysis of environmental legislation and its governance currently being developed to be completed in year 2

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
2.2 Learn-by-doing integration of Rio Conventions into select environmental legislation
Three Rio Convention technical working groups established under the MEA Technical Committees
Draft agreement on information sharing (see output 1.2)
Modified enforcement of existing national environmental legislation per Rio Convention obligation
High quality progress reports and independent assessment of legislative reforms.
Expert workshops convened to regularly assess conflicts between environmental legislation
Best practice and lesson learned reports

baseline.comment:
2.2 Learn-by-doing integration of Rio Conventions into select environmental legislation
Technical working groups and workshops under Rio Conventions are not institutionalized by rather temporary organizational mechanisms under focal area projects
There is no formal or institutional agreement on the sharing of information across ministries, agencies or non-state actors
Numerous progress reports are prepared and submitted resulting in an over-burdening of government staff and low commitment, but these remain targeted to focal area priorities
Expert meetings do not adequately address the cross-cutting barriers to effective implementation of national environmental legislation
Development partners in Costa Rica are committed to supporting the country’s improved access to better data and information on innovative approaches to meeting global environmental objectives.

target.comment:
2.2 Learn-by-doing integration of Rio Conventions into select environmental legislation
Three Rio Convention technical working groups are created and meet by month 7 of the project and at least twice (2x) per year.
Technical working groups present their findings and recommendations to the MEA technical committees by month and subsequently within one month of convening.
Technical working group draft a non-legally binding agreement on the mutual sharing of information among each other and with the government by month 12 of the project
Three policy recommendations piloted and completed by month 26
Government agencies and departments responsible for testing policy recommendations submit quarterly progress reports to the MEA technical committees every three months with the first no later than month 12.
Two (2) expert workshops with at least 30 relevant key actors each, organized and concluded by month 18
Three (3) best practice and lessons learned reports are prepared on targeted regional Rio Convention mainstreaming activities by month 12, month 23, and month 33
Technical guidelines are drafted and finalized by month 24
Policy recommendations to legitimize these guidelines, as appropriate, are prepared, submitted, and approved by the Inter-Ministerial Council by month 28

actual.comment: Three Rio Convention technical working groups set up. These working groups have planned a series of inter-sectorial dialogues, particular in climate change, which is to be reported for year 2. The National Policy Framework on Biodiversity is also being discussed through stakeholder consultations, and the results will be shared in the next reporting period.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
2.3 Strengthened monitoring and compliance
Monitoring and compliance indicators
Monitoring and compliance assessment reports
Monitoring and compliance guidelines and tools
Policy decisions on legislative and institutional reforms to reconcile and harmonize environmental and related legislation to conform with Rio Convention obligations
Training workshops on monitoring of and compliance with environmental legislation
Number of relevant government staff having clear present and potential future roles in monitoring and compliance

baseline.comment:
2.3 Strengthened monitoring and compliance
There are no clear monitoring or compliance indicators to assess the extent to which Rio Convention obligations are being delivered through existing national environmental legislation
Monitoring reports are internal documents that have unclear value to planners and decision-makers
Monitoring and compliance guidelines and tools are not widely known among planners and decision-makers
Inter-Ministerial Council focuses on climate change, but there is no equivalent policy decision-making mechanism that is as effective on biodiversity or land degradation
Trainings to take place on environment-related issues, however these remain targeted to focal area issues, with inadequate attention to environmental legislative reforms

target.comment:
2.3 Strengthened monitoring and compliance
Clear monitoring and compliance reforms submitted to the MEA technical committee after three monitoring phases: by month 12, by month 23, and by month 33
Quarterly progress reports are submitted to the MEA technical committees every three months, beginning by month 15
Lessons learned of pilot monitoring and compliance reforms discussed in a stakeholder constituent dialogue by month 22
Survey of N100 experts and other stakeholders by month 22 and a second survey by month 33 rate successful piloting of monitoring and compliance reforms
MEA technical committee proposes monitoring and compliance reforms to institutionalize best practice monitoring and compliance procedures by month 32
Inter-Ministerial Council authorizes at least 80% of MEA technical committee recommended reforms by month 34
Report on guidelines, tools and resources for the effective interpretation, supervision and enforcement of environmental legislation completed by month 8
New guidelines, tools, and other resources are available through the electronic platform by month 12
Comprehensive training programme drafted by month 18 and endorsed by the MEA technical committees by month 20
Four (4) training workshops and related exercises begin by month 20
At least 80 government staff members that are directly implicated in the planning and decision-making process to monitor and enforce environmental legislation have participated in training workshops by month 33
Operational guidelines are drafted and finalized by month 24 and validated by month 26
Policy recommendations to legitimize these guidelines, as appropriate, are prepared, submitted, and approved by the Inter-Ministerial Council by month 28

actual.comment: Consultant hired to help design the monitoring and compliance system within MINAE for the implementation of the Rio Conventions. Recommendations for reforms will be completed and submitted to MEA technical committee by Year 2

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
3.1 Kick-Off and Project Results Conferences
One-day Kick-Off Conference to raise high profile of project
One-day Project Results Conference to showcase lessons learned and best practices
Four (4) expert panel discussions on Rio Convention sub-themes

baseline.comment:
3.1 Kick-Off and Project Results Conferences
? The environmental movement in Costa Rica is relatively strong compared to other countries, and there is an overall strong interest among the NGO community and population to learn about innovative opportunities to catalyze environmental action
? Development partners in Costa Rica are committed to supporting the country’s improved access to better data and information on innovative approaches to meeting global environmental objectives.

target.comment:
3.1 Kick-Off and Project Results Conferences
? One-day Kick-Off Conference is held by month 3
? One-day Project Results Conference is held by month 34
? Over 200 participants attend both the Kick-Off and Project Results conferences, representing a good diversity of stakeholders, including representation from other regions of Costa Rica
? At least four (4) expert panel discussions present the lessons learned to deliver Rio Convention obligations through existing national environmental and related legislation
? At least 30 participants attend each of the panel discussions

actual.comment: One-day Kick-Off Conference held in March 2015 with high profile participation by Minister of the Environment, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs and UNDP Resident Coordinator. National workshop on the UN Convention on Biological Diversity held in February, paved the way for the finalization of the National Biodiversity Strategy and for the launch of the National Policy on Biodiversity.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
3.2 Public awareness campaign, survey, and educational materials
? Analysis of Costa Rica’s environmental values (survey results)
? Public awareness plan on national environmental legislation and Rio Conventions
? Articles on legislative responses to implement Rio Conventions
? High School competition plan
? Education module on environmental legislation and Rio Conventions implemented
? Public Service Announcement airings on television and radio that promote compliance with existing environmental legislation

baseline.comment:
3.2 Public awareness campaign, survey, and educational materials
Awareness and understanding of the Rio Conventions in Costa Rica is relatively good compared to other countries. However, this is not as effectively translated into compliance with environmental legislation, further exacerbated by conflicting provisions of environmental and natural resource management legislation and regulation

target.comment:
3.2 Public awareness campaign, survey, and educational materials
? Two broad-based surveys (N500) completed by month 3 and by month 34
? Expert and independent analysis of the survey results completed by month 35
? A comprehensive public awareness plan developed to completed by month 6
? At least nine (9) articles on legislative responses for Rio Convention implementation in Costa Rica published in popular literature with high circulation before the end of the project. By month 6, at least one article should be published. By month 18, at least four (4) articles should be published. By month 30, at least seven (7) articles should be published.
? Each article edited and published as a brochure, with at least 100 copies each and distributed to at least two high value special events
? High school competition plan for completed by month 9
? At least two (2) high schools carry out high school competitions by month 20; at least six (6) by month 33
? Education module prepared for high schools completed by month 8
? At least two (2) high schools have implemented education module by month 20 and at least one high school in each of the seven provinces by month 33
? One PSA completed for both television and radio (audio version) by month 12, with the first airing by month 15.
? At least 50 airings of the PSA on television and at least 100 airings of the PSA on radio, both by month 34

actual.comment: No public awareness campaigns have been launched during the reporting period

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
3.3 Awareness-raising dialogues and workshops
? Awareness workshops targeted to the private sector, journalists, local and regional government representatives on national environmental legislation and the Rio Conventions
? Survey data on environmental attitudes and values (activity 3.2.1)
? Expert MEA legislative mainstreaming workshops (complements learn-by-doing workshops of output 2.2)
? Cutting-edge panel discussions by leaders in the environmental field on environmental legislation for meeting Rio Convention obligations

baseline.comment:
3.3 Awareness-raising dialogues and workshops
? Media professionals generally have no special training of Rio Convention issues, in particularly of the linkages between non-compliance of national environmental legislation and global environmental impacts
? The private sector is primarily focused on traditional approaches to maximizing profits, seeing environmental issues as an added transaction cost that reduces profits
? Public dialogues take place through the construct of donor-funded projects on focal areas and do not adequately address the conflicting impacts on other environmental priorities
? Regional government representatives are not adequately familiar with approaches to meet Rio Convention obligations given their heightened obligations to meet socio-economic development priorities within their short-term regional development plans
? The general public in Costa Rica is generally aware and concerned about global environmental issues, but increasingly behaviour is detached from these values due to increasing socio-economic pressures and in the absence of innovative approaches to comply with existing environmental legislation

target.comment:
3.3 Awareness-raising dialogues and workshops
Three (3) panel discussions, with at least 20 private sector representatives the completed by month 8; the second by month 18; and the third by month 28
At least three (3) journalist awareness workshops held, each with at least 10 representatives the first completed by month 9; the second by month 19; and the third by month 29
By month 33, reporting on Rio Convention mainstreaming in the popular media shows a 10% increase over forecasted trends using baseline data and past trends
At least three (3) workshops of MEA legislative mainstreaming are convened with at least 20 expert practitioner participants the first completed by month 10; the second by month 20; and the third by month 30
At least three (3) regional workshops are convened, with local and regional government representatives with at least one representative from each of the seven Costa Rican provinces having participated in at least one workshop. Each workshop should be attended by at least 20 local/regional representatives. The first regional workshop should be completed by month 11; the second by month 21; and the third by month 31
Three (3) cutting-edge policy dialogues with invited leaders in the field of environmental governance the first dialogue convened by month 7; the second by month 17; and the third by month 27

actual.comment: Workshop held for the launch of the Campaign "Clean your Footprint" from the MINAE to help raise awareness of the need to reduce carbon emissions, save wáter and reduce urban waste. WOrkshop was held in the auditorium of La Nación, a major national newspaper, and attended by over 60 people, including private sector, NGOs, reporters and journalists from several media.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
3.4 Resource mobilization strategy
Resource mobilization strategy report
Feasibility study on financial and economic instruments to advance monitoring and compliance of existing environmental legislation to meet Rio Convention obligations
Expert working group established

baseline.comment:
3.4 Resource mobilization strategy
Costa Rica benefits from significant interest from the donor community to finance capacity development actions to meet global environmental objectives
Government of Costa Rica is very committed to taking a uniquely innovative and transformative approach to meeting Rio Convention obligations within existing environmental legislative frameworks to reduce the dependence of official development assistance, which is not sustainable.

target.comment:
3.4 Resource mobilization strategy
Analytical report drafted, peer reviewed, and finalized by month 12
Feasibility study on financial and economic instruments to advance the monitoring and compliance of environmental legislation for the global environment completed by month 18
Expert working group is made up of at least 20 rotating members, who will undertake a desk review of the drafts of the analytical report and feasibility study, and meet at least once to discuss the findings of each within one month of their completion, i.e., by months 13 and 19

actual.comment: Meetings held with the new Country Focal point for the Green Climate Fund (GCF). A visit by the regional coordinator of the GCF was attended by national institutions, private sector, banking institutions and NGOs. A resource mobilization strategy will be drafted, peer reviewed and finalized during Year 2

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
3.5 Internet visibility of integrated and streamlined environmental legislation
Website promotes Rio Convention obligations through existing national environmental and natural resource management legislation
Facebook page on environmental legislation for the Rio Conventions

baseline.comment:
3.5 Internet visibility of integrated and streamlined environmental legislation
There are a number of websites promoting environmental issues in Costa Rica. However, none are specific to environmental legislation. MINAE is committed to strengthen a comprehensive website that will provide a one-stop shop for understanding how to better interpret existing environmental and related legislation to meet both sustainable development and global environmental priorities.
Development partners in Costa Rica are committed to supporting the country’s improved access to better data and information on innovative approaches to meeting global environmental objectives.

target.comment:
3.5 Internet visibility of integrated and streamlined environmental legislation
Feasibility study for the creation of a comprehensive environment legislation website prepared and completed by month 4
Website architecture completed and endorsed by the MEA technical working group by month 6
Website is updated at least once a month with new information, articles, and resources
Website statistical data rank the quality of the website (unique users, visit sessions, and page views) as a consistent top ten site of all Costa Rican websites by the twelfth month of being online and throughout the project’s three years of implementation.
Facebook page created by month 3 and updated on a weekly basis, at minimum
At least 2,000 Facebook likes by month 32

actual.comment: Website development still pending. Planned for Year 2
